div1.p: Hench thanks Purdy for his interest in the book he is preparing. However, he has not yet begun to write the first draft.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Theodore M. Purdy, February 18, 1948
div1.opener:
y. f.
February 18, 1948
Mr. Theodore M. Purdy, Editor
Trade Books
D. Appleton-Century Company
35 West 32nd Street
New York 1, New York
My dear Mr. Purdy:
div1.p:
I have been out of town attending medical meetings, hence my delay
in answering your kind letter of January 20, expressing an interest in the
book which I have in preparation on the subject of “The Conquest of Yellow
Fever” (or “Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever” or some more attrac-
tive title). I am coming along with this book fairly well, but still slowly.
I have probably collected 90% of what I eventually hope to have, but there are
still one or two “holes” in my material which I hope to plug up this year. In
the meantime, I have made a preliminary break-down of my material and find that
it could be arranged in about 35 chapters. However, perhaps I had better com-
bine it so as to make a smaller number of chapters.

I have not even begun to write the first draft; however, I have on
occasion summarized the whole thing (in the briefest fashion) and given it
as an illustrated lecture, which always seems to be very well received. The
last time I gave the lecture was before the faculty and medical students of
the University of Virginia Medical School (where Reed graduated) on the oc-
casion of the Alpha Omega Alpha honorary medical fraternity barquet last fall.
I did not publish the lecture as such but was asked for about 25 copies so I
had it multigraphed and am sending you one.

I do not want to commit myself to any time or anybody but I do greatly
appreciate the interest of yourself and Mr. McDermott. I have made no commit-
ments to anybody else but Schuman, the New York Medical Book publisher, also
writes me about it from time to time. On the basis of your broader coverage,
I am certainly more pleased with your interest than that of Schuman.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
